newsitem.title: SPAIN: GOLF-AMES LEADS WHILE ALLENBY HITS SINGLE SHOT FOR CHARITY.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-AMES LEADS WHILE ALLENBY HITS SINGLE SHOT FOR CHARITY.

text.p: After travelling 19,000 km (12,000 miles) to hit a golf ball, ailing Australian Robert Allenby struck it 35 metres for charity before pulling out of the Volvo Masters on Thursday.

As Stephen Ames of Trinidad took the first round lead later in the day with a four-under-par 67, Allenby, his fractured sternum still throbbing with pain, was already on his way home via the United States after fulfilling a European Tour requirement that he play in the season-ending tournament to be eligible for his bonus.
At third place on the money list, his share of a 600,000 pounds ($960,000) end-of-season kitty would be 73,000 pounds ($117,00), 53,000 pounds ($85,000) if, as likely, he falls to fourth place.
Whatever the amount, Allenby will donate it to two children's charities, the Teenage Cancer Trust UK and the Challenge Cancer Support Network in Australia.

"I was not here for the money. I merely wanted to protect my position on the money list for the year because I think I deserve it," said the 25-year-old winner of the French and English Opens and the British Masters this year.
"I'll probably hit a shot like a five-year-old," Allenby, who flew from his Melbourne home on Wednesday, said when he arrived at the Valderrama course on Thursday morning.
As a morning fog lent a surreal air to an already farcical situation, Allenby did just that, his shot with a three wood looking more like a putt as it trickled down the fairway a mere 35 yards.
"I felt a sharp pain on the follow-through," he said of the injury that he sustained in car crash in the nearby town of Estepona four weeks ago.
"It hurts when I sneeze, laugh or breath. It feels like there's an axe in there," he said.

Allenby had no quarrel with the rule that led to what was almost a cameo appearance, though Ryder Cup captain Seve Ballesteros said he felt it was unfair a player had to travel so far to hit just one shot.

Ballesteros offered no solution to the situation though he seemed to agree with a suggestion from Colin Montgomerie on Wednesday that the bonus money be made part of the tournament prize fund instead of being offered separately.
Ames, winner of the Benson and Hedges International in May, was surprised with his 67 after taking three weeks off because of repeated problems with his swing.
"I just wanted to come here and enjoy the game, accept what I shot and hopefully play four rounds," said Ames, who dropped out after three rounds of his only previous Masters appearance in 1993.
Four birdies over the back nine helped him to a one-stroke lead over Britons Gordon Brand jnr, who holed a 95-yard wedge shot for an eagle three at the 535-yard fourth, and Paul Curry.

Irishman Padraig Harrington aced the 173-yard third hole with a seven iron on the way to a two-under-par 69 and a share of fourth place with Britons Jim Payne and Paul Lawrie and Costantino Rocca of Italy.
Rocca could displace Allenby from third spot on the money list with a fifth placing or better finish.

The big names did not fare well. Montgomerie, whose opening shot assured him of the number one position for a fourth successive year, carded a level-par 71. "And I was very fortunmate to do that," he said.
Ian Woosnam, second on the list, carded a 76 after accidentally breaking his putter following a birdie four at the fourth. He putted with a one iron for the rest of the round.
Ballesteros, still suffering from a heavy cold, had a three-over par 74 that included a triple bogey six at the tough 212-yard 12th, where he sliced his first shot 50 yards to the right, out of play.
Bernhard Langer, needing a victory to extend his record of winning at least one tour title every year to 17 years, shot 73.
